  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.ASTIdentifier.execute(ASTIdentifier.java:223)
  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.ASTReference.execute(ASTReference.java:262)
  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.ASTReference.evaluate(ASTReference.java:470)
  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.ASTNotNode.evaluate(ASTNotNode.java:63)
  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.ASTExpression.evaluate(ASTExpression.java:62)
  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.ASTIfStatement.render(ASTIfStatement.java:85)
  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.ASTBlock.render(ASTBlock.java:72)

  at org.apache.velocity.runtime.parser.node.SimpleNode.render(SimpleNode.java:336)
  at org.apache.velocity.Template.merge(Template.java:328)
  at org.apache.velocity.Template.merge(Template.java:235)

h3.Workaround
The workaround is to delete the comments that this user has. To do that, first we'll grab the user_key of the affected user, then we'll run three queries to delete the entries.
(!) Please, save a backup copy of your database before running any of the queries below.

{code:sql}
SELECT user_key
FROM user_mapping
WHERE username = 'affected_username';
{code}
* Replace the *affected_username* with the proper username that is affected by the bug.

{code:sql}
DELETE FROM BODYCONTENT WHERE CONTENTID IN (SELECT CONTENTID FROM CONTENT WHERE CREATOR='affected_user_key' AND CONTENTTYPE='COMMENT');
{code}
{code:sql}
DELETE FROM CONTENTPROPERTIES WHERE CONTENTID IN (SELECT CONTENTID FROM CONTENT WHERE CREATOR='affected_user_key' AND CONTENTTYPE='COMMENT');
{code}
{code:sql}
DELETE FROM CONTENT WHERE CREATOR='affected_user_key' AND CONTENTTYPE='COMMENT';
{code}

(!) Make sure to replace the *affected_user_key* value with the proper user_key.

Try to delete the user in the UI again after running the queries above and restarting Confluence. You might need to log in with the user and discard any drafts if you still can't delete the user and is sure that the user didn't create any content.

fields.description:
# Start Confluence in DC mode
 # Find or create any LDAP user directory
 # Edit this directory
 # Notice the exceptions in logs of any other node

The root cause

When {{DirectorySynchroniserHelperImpl#handleEvent}} fires from cluster event, we have no valid transaction. The code tries to update DB and fails.

The right solution right here is not to call this particular handle when directory state was changed on the other node. This can be achieved by:
 # Subclass {{DirectoryUpdateEvent}} by {{AnotherNodeDirectoryUpdateEvent}}
 # Use this subclass in {{ConfluenceDirectoryEventListener#onApplicationEvent}}. It is required to know in the handler whether the event came from this node or from another one.
 # Override {{DirectorySynchroniserHelperImpl#handleEvent}} in subclass and check for the event for instance of {{AnotherNodeDirectoryUpdateEvent}}. If this is the case, we should do nothing (another node will update the DB)

Also there is a problem that we don't have any transaction when this manipulation occur. It doesn't cause any error right now because we process the event in sync mode. But it will be good practice to create manual transaction here (via {{PlatformTransactionManager}} and {{TransactionTemplate}})

Maybe there are more places where we do meaningless work on each node

h3. Summary
When a user edits a page to a page and the window forcibly closes (without being saved as a draft), the "unpublished changes" lozenge shows up next to the page name under the "Recently Worked On" section without prompting the user again with a discard changes option or to show changes made in the past.

h3. Environment
* Can be reproduced in 6.7.0, 6.7.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a test page with content and publish (to mimic existing content)
# Go to the page and add a string of words
# Close the Confluence window (the page will not be saved as a draft or be discarded)
# Open Confluence and see the page with the "unpublished changes" lozenge next to it
# If you click on the page with unpublished changes, don't make any changes (even though there are pending changes from step #2), and you click the close link in the bottom right. Confluence doesn't prompt you with the "Close the editor" screen to show changes, discard all changes, or keep as draft, for modification you made in a past session.

Another scenario with the same results:
# Create a test page with content and publish (to mimic existing content)
# Go to the page and add a string of words
# Click *Close* in the bottom right corner and click *Keep Draft* on the "Close the editor" screen
# Locate the draft in *Recently Worked On" section (where the page will display with an *Unpublished Changes* lozenge to the right of it
# Click on that page and then click *Edit*
# Click CLOSE without making any more changes
#* You will not be prompted with "Close the Editor" screen

h3. Expected Results
When there are pending unpublished changes on any page, Confluence should show a discard or keep changes prompt.

h3. Actual Results
If there are pending unpublished changes on a page not saved as a draft and you click edit to see the changes made before publishing, the page just closes without the keep/discard changes prompt.
 
h3. Notes
Only if you make a change to the page on the secondary session, will you get the prompt to keep as a draft or discard changes. This has major impact since the user cannot view or discard changes made to a page if they choose to not save it as a draft immediately.

h3.Workaround
Add a small change (such as a space) to the document after clicking edit on the unpublished changes page. Only then will Confluence recognize the change made during the previous and current session when clicking the "Close" option in the bottom corner of the page.
fields.summary: Close prompt to discard changes or view changes doesn't show when there were changes made in a "unpublished changes" page

h3. Summary
Drafts created by Confluence questions, which appear under *User Profile > Drafts*, cannot be discarded or edited.

h3. Environment
* Confluence 6.2.x (Likely any version)
* Confluence Questions 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Confluence Questions
# Create a question 
# Select a space from "Ask in a space"
# Enter a question title, description, and select a topic
# Before clicking save, a draft will appear in *User Profile > Drafts*

There appears to be a new draft created each time these steps are repeated. 

It should be noted that during repro testing, it sometimes took a minute or two for the drafts to appear.

h3. Expected Results
* After clicking Discard on the draft in User Profile > Drafts, the draft is discarded.
* After clicking Resume on the draft in User Profile > Drafts, the draft is Editable.

h3. Actual Results
Clicking Discard or Resume results in a Page Not Found error displayed in the browser.

The below exception is thrown in the browser console log:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
{statusCode: 400, data: {authorized: true, valid: false, errors: [{message: {,…}}], successful: false},…}
data
:
{authorized: true, valid: false, errors: [{message: {,…}}], successful: false}
message
:
"Draft deletion is not supported for type: com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-questions:answer-draft. It must be a PAGE or BLOGPOST."
statusCode
:
400
{code}

h3.Workaround


A temporary workaround is to change the draft status from the database.
# Find the content ID of the drafts.
#* It can be found by hovering the cursor over the draft in Confluence and then finding the *draftID* from the URL.
(!) Please take a backup of Confluence database before running the following command.
# Update <content id> in the following SQL query by substituting the *draftID* from the above step.
{code:sql}
update content set content_status = 'deleted' where contentid = <content id>;
{code}
# After the above step, we have to refresh cache.
 # In Confluence, navigate to *General Configuration* > *Cache Management*
 # Look for *Content Objects* and select *Flush*

(i) Alternatively, it is possible to locate all the drafts that fall into this state with the SQL query below:
{code}
select * from content where pluginkey='com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-questions:answer-draft' and content_status='draft';
{code}

As a Confluence System Administrator, I do not want to manage all the groups that a Space may wish to implement.

For example, we have a desire to have several different groups for a particular space that we can then control page access/rights based on that membership.  We could certainly manage these with individual permissions.  However, we will have hundreds of users in the "view" group and only dozens of users in the other groups.  It will be very difficult to manage hundreds of individual user access rights on the Space Permissions page.  It would be much easy to have a defined access rights by group and then add users to the appropriate access group rather than adding each user in the space permissions and checking the boxes based on their access needs.  This needs to be managed by the Space Admin and NOT by the Confluence Admin.

Another option would be to add another Global Permission that is less powerful than System and Confluence admin.  My suggestion is Group admin.

Or, finally, you allow total customize rights for permissions.  Then, I as System Admin can create my own group that I will give permission for group management.  (Obviously, the Group Admin would not be able to manage groups that have authority above their own rights.  So, a Group Admin would not be able to change the System or Confluence Admin group membership.)

# Remove access for the confluence-users group
# Log in as the admin user and navigate to this space

h3. Expected Results
Going to any page in the space should still show an Edit button, and the 'e' shortcut should open up the editor.

h3. Actual Results
Edit will not appear on any pages in the space, the 'e' shortcut will not open the editor.
 
h3. Notes
This appears to be caused by changes made in 5.10. Previously the Edit button would show, but attempts to edit would cause a "Not Permitted" error

h3.Solution / Workaround
* Add confluence-administrators group to the default global space permissions
** This permission will need to be added individually to existing spaces
fields.summary: Members of confluence-administrators group cannot edit pages unless given explicit permission

Analytics logs are stored in shared-home, and they appear to never be cleaned out. We have an instance which has over 6gb of these logfiles. When space is limited this could cause shared-home to fill up and run out of disk space, in extreme cases this can cause outages.

{code}[person@confluence ~]$ sudo du -h /media/atl/confluence/shared-home/analytics-logs/
6.1G	/media/atl/confluence/shared-home/analytics-logs/{code}

There should be log rotation, or a scheduled job to clear these out periodically.
fields.summary: Analytics log directory does not clear on a schedule

h3. Summary

When re-editing an *Issue Statistics* macro for a page, the preview section on the editing section does not fully expand, effectively cropping the settings window and making it difficult to set the properties for the macro.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Edit Confluence page with the Issue Statistics macro on it.
 # Edit the Issue Statistics macro.
 # On the Preview pane click Edit (to alter parameters like Saved Filter or Statistics Type)
 # Scroll to bottom of the gadget settings window and click SAVE or CANCEL
 # Now click Edit (in the Preview pane) again.

h3. Expected Results

When clicking on *Edit* for the Preview pane, the frame should full expand and provide access to all settings.
h3. Actual Results

Instead, the screen crops off as shown below:

!screen1.png|width=623,height=382!
h3. Workaround

Currently, the workaround for this issue is that you have to either _tab_ through each section or remove and then re-add the *Issue Statistics* Macro.
fields.summary: Preview pane for Issue Statistics macro cuts off when re-editing

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, the "Recent Spaces" menu shows the 10 most recent spaces visited in Confluence.

There is no option to adjust this, either globally or per-user.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide ability to show how many recent spaces will display for a user or globally, able to be adjusted by the Confluence Administrator.
fields.summary: Ability to modify count of "Recent Spaces" list in Confluence
